posts.title: Supreme Court rejects Trump’s request to keep billions in foreign aid frozen
top_comments:
Alito’s dissent is some choice bullshit. “How dare a lower court override the president!”

The lower court found that congress had specified money to be spent, and the executive branch can’t just say “Nah.” They can slow walk it, they can do some other shady shit - but in the end they gotta pay out that money. 

Alito’s so concerned about someone overturning the president he’s saying the statutes congress passed don’t matter.

It’s kind of mind boggling that 4 Supreme Court Justices support the idea that the Executive branch can just deicide not to pay their bills when the Legislative branch has allocated the funding and the recipients have already done what they were to be paid to do.
OK, so now let’s see if trump complies and if he doesn’t, then what?
Damn Justice Amy Coney Barrett doing justice.

That there are only five SCOTUS votes for paying congressionally mandated invoices for work *already* done!? This should be as basic a test of Article I as you can get. And that does not bode well for decisions to come

“Four of the court’s conservatives — Justices Clarence Thomas, Samuel Alito, Neil Gorsuch and Brett Kavanaugh — dissented.”

These are the men who will dismantle our democracy. 

So shocked by Coney Barrett. I guess he does understand the Constitution and the benefit of rule of law. 

BTW- this ruling merely states that the USG must pay for work already done by implementers. This is money owed to them.
Hallelujah. I haven’t been keeping up too much with which justices vote for what so maybe this is normal, but I was surprised to see Amy Coney Barrett voted with the liberal justices.

Interesting that 2 conservatives, including 1 Trump appointee in Barrett ruled against Trump. Though maybe not so much considering how relatively extreme this case is. The decision to spend this money is made by Congress and the executive branch, in theory, shouldn't be able to stop it for long.

What will be more interesting(albeit also scary and dangerous) is what happens if the executive branch starts to ignore judicial rulings that they don't like.

If Congress sits around and concedes authority to the executive branch and the judicial branch turns out to be toothless, that kind of defeats the whole checks and balances concept that we've leaned on for so long. From there the executive can do whatever, no?

So, it looks like this isn't a particularly strong ruling against Trump, despite the headline, given that it basically shifts responsibility back down to the lower court.

At least that's something, I guess?

In any case, we'll see if Trump decides to Jackson this.
Whenever I hear even moderately good news from SCOTUS, I immediately fear that it's a bone being thrown to the Left right before an awful ruling for Trump.

posts.title: Piglets left to starve as part of a controversial art exhibition in Denmark have been stolen
top_comments:
Good on the activists who stole them and the guy who helped. This artist is nuts. What an awful person.

 This just seems extra cruel for no real end game, like its not going to stop anyone from anything, it was suffering for the sake of "art".
This the same artist that did the goldfish in blenders?
This is not art it’s animal cruelty

> Chilean-born Marco Evaristti said he had been aiming to raise awareness of the suffering caused by mass meat production with his art installation that opened last week in Copenhagen. The piglets were being denied food and water and would have been allowed to starve to death.

I don't think the way to advocate against animal cruelty, is to cause more animal cruelty. Especially when you're subjecting a creature to a slow death that is initially pretty agonizing.
Suffering for his art is probably a good thing. Replace the missing pigs in the cage with the artist - maybe it will make the same point.

It is kind of interesting that everyone is very upset by this but not upset when it is done in factory farms. I think that is the point of this. Not defending it but I wish some of you would reflect on how this mirrors industrial farming techniques.
I’m inclined to think this artist is actually a psychopath.  Performing animal cruelty to point out other people’s cruelty is certainly a choice.

There was an artist a while back who did something like this with a dog. Guillermo Vargas brought in a starving street dog from outside and had it in the art gallery for 3 hours - the gallery reported that he did feed it food and water while it was there, before it "escaped." Guests were shocked and complained about it, and the artist's point was basically, it's the same dog you walked past outside but didn't give a shit about.

I'm going out on a limb here and braving the wall of downvotes.


The provocation artist achived what he wanted without harming the piglets. They were never starved, they were not even showcased.


Yet he managed to upset so many people, that it sparked an outrage highlighting the fact most people don't give two shits about animals dying, as long as they are out of sight. What can be more artful than getting people to reflect on issues they normally wouldn't?


The comments in this post are beyond disappointing and shows they have no grasp on art at all.

Maybe, just maybe, the theft of the piglets is all part of the art exhibition. I’m not sure this is the case given that the exhibition opened last week. 

If the intention was to allow three piglets to die from thirst there is a special place in hell for the artist. 

“Chilean-born Marco Evaristti said he had been aiming to raise awareness of the suffering caused by mass meat production with his art installation that opened last week in Copenhagen. The piglets were being denied food and water and would have been allowed to starve to death.”

They wouldn’t have starved to death, they would have died of thirst.

Well..wtf did they think was going to happen.  They flood the zone with unemployed govt workers and now China want the skills so they can build up their govt etc.  These fucks do stupid shit and wonder why stuff happens.  People won't sit around and suffer after you fire them.  They have families to feed.  They don't give a fk.  Whoever pay will get their services. I don't blame them. The US is unstable

I keep saying it, but all of this private industry push is **profoundly** anti-American. There are private companies and money *all over the world.* The GOP in America *says* they are pro-America, but there isn't, and will never be, a policy that restricts private companies (and their money) to come to America and stay--because the world is big. There will always, always be money elsewhere and companies elsewhere. 

You want to make America great? Improve America's ability to compete. That's all you can do.

THE ARTICLE TITLE IS MISLEADING AND A LIE. 

Trump didnt do anything and the EOs and Presidential memorandums directing for a massive downsizing of the federal government are still in place. All that happened was that the Office of Personnel and Management (OPM), which is kinda like the whole governments HR and who makes policies, rescinded a memo that they wrote implementing the Presidential EOs and Memoranda. This was done because OPM can’t legally tell other departments to fire people and the Courts have pointed that out in some injunctions and court cases that have been brought. 

THIS MEMO BEING RESCINDED DOES NOTHING OTHER THAN TELL AGENCIES THEY NEED TO MAKE THE DETERMINATION TO FIRE PROBATIONARY (new) EMPLOYEES ‘THEMSELVES’. posts.title: NYS Corrections enters its third weeks of wildcat strikes; more than 8000 COs still on strike
FIRE files federal lawsuit against top Texas A&M administrators
top_comments:
“The Foundation for Individual Rights and Expression, or FIRE, has filed a federal lawsuit against the nine members of the Board of Regents, Chancellor John Sharp and Texas A&M President Mark A. Welsh III on behalf of the Queer Empowerment Council, the student organization that hosts and organizes Draggieland.”

Keep the lawsuits coming. Freedom of speech, freedom from persecution and discrimination are the building blocks of our democracy.

What ever happened to just not attending if you're not interested? I mean, it's not the sort of thing I'd go out of my way to see, but I can always just... you know... not attend. When I was in college there would occasionally be some wandering preacher guy who'd show up on campus for a couple days. I wasn't really interested in his message, so I just kept walking. A very simple and elegant solution that didn't involve me trying to impose my personal beliefs on anyone else. I just would have appreciated someone from the campus security doing a bit of crowd control since people listening would often block the entire sidewalk which was a major thoroughfare.

And honestly, nothing beats the name of a SF group: The Sisters of Perpetual Indulgence

posts.title: Human ancestors made the oldest known bone tools 1.5 million years ago
top_comments:
The idea the the oldest bone tools ever discovered could have been made by a hominin species that is not a direct ancestor to modern humans is so cool. Paranthropus Boisei was an australopithecine. We already know they probably used bone tools around 1.3 million years ago but this is an amazing find that pushes that date back further.

  
I wish we knew more about the exchange of technology between different hominin species. Although I think both species would be intelligent enough to find a hippo femur and think "hell yeah look at this massive bone!" and keep it.

>Ancient human relatives crafted sharp-edged tools out of animal bones around 1.5 million years ago, researchers say.

>Discoveries at Tanzania’s Olduvai Gorge, a famous East African fossil location, represent the oldest known evidence of systematic bone tool production by hominids, according to archaeologist Ignacio de la Torre of CSIC-Spanish National Research Council in Madrid and colleagues.

>Excavations conducted from 2015 through 2022 [unearthed 27 bone tools](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-025-08652-5) in sediment that had already been dated, the scientists report March 5 in *Nature*. Either of two fossil hominids known to have lived at Olduvai Gorge around 1.5 million years ago — a possible direct human ancestor called *Homo erectus* or [a side-branch species dubbed *Paranthropus boisei*](https://www.sciencenews.org/article/no-nuts-you-nutcracker-man) — could have created the bone artifacts, they say.

Read [more here ](https://www.sciencenews.org/article/human-ancestors-oldest-bone-tools)and the [research article ](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-025-08652-5)here.
Now I'm gonna have Strauss stick in my head all day.
Well yeah.. when bob die, pinky toe make for great toothpick.
Interesting. I hope I get to use my bone tool tonight.
Ha, some deny the planet is that old.
And it was all downhill from there

posts.title: BSO returned handgun used in Tamarac killing spree to accused killer: Records
top_comments:
More than a dozen guns and a cache of ammunition were seized from Nathan Gingles, but it was all returned to him after Mary Catherine Gingles dropped the first domestic violence injunction.

The handgun and suppressor police believe was used to kill a Tamarac mother, her father and her neighbor last month was returned to the accused killer by the Broward Sheriff’s Office, according to recently obtained records.

The handgun and suppressor police believe was used to kill a Tamarac mother, her father and her neighbor last month was returned to the accused killer by the Broward Sheriff's Office, according to recently obtained records.

NBC6 Investigates confirmed Tuesday that in all, more than a dozen guns were seized along with a cache of ammunition – but it was all returned to Nathan Gingles in August after Mary Catherine Gingles dropped the first domestic violence injunction.

But in January, deputies were ordered by a judge to re-confiscate them after a second injunction was granted, but they did not.

That failure and others in the case have led to eight deputies being suspended and a captain demoted, pending an internal investigation.

Records released Tuesday show 18 police calls to the house in the year before the killings.

Mary Gingles and her father, David Ponzer, were both killed in front of her 4-year-old daughter, along with a neighbor, Andrew Ferrin, whose house Mary Gingles ran to for help.
I have always wondered why a silencer is required for self defence.

posts.title: Supreme Court rejects Trump’s request to keep billions in foreign aid frozen
top_comments:
Alito’s dissent is some choice bullshit. “How dare a lower court override the president!”

The lower court found that congress had specified money to be spent, and the executive branch can’t just say “Nah.” They can slow walk it, they can do some other shady shit - but in the end they gotta pay out that money. 

Alito’s so concerned about someone overturning the president he’s saying the statutes congress passed don’t matter.

It’s kind of mind boggling that 4 Supreme Court Justices support the idea that the Executive branch can just deicide not to pay their bills when the Legislative branch has allocated the funding and the recipients have already done what they were to be paid to do.
OK, so now let’s see if trump complies and if he doesn’t, then what?
Damn Justice Amy Coney Barrett doing justice.

That there are only five SCOTUS votes for paying congressionally mandated invoices for work *already* done!? This should be as basic a test of Article I as you can get. And that does not bode well for decisions to come

“Four of the court’s conservatives — Justices Clarence Thomas, Samuel Alito, Neil Gorsuch and Brett Kavanaugh — dissented.”

These are the men who will dismantle our democracy. 

So shocked by Coney Barrett. I guess he does understand the Constitution and the benefit of rule of law. 

BTW- this ruling merely states that the USG must pay for work already done by implementers. This is money owed to them.
Hallelujah. I haven’t been keeping up too much with which justices vote for what so maybe this is normal, but I was surprised to see Amy Coney Barrett voted with the liberal justices.

Interesting that 2 conservatives, including 1 Trump appointee in Barrett ruled against Trump. Though maybe not so much considering how relatively extreme this case is. The decision to spend this money is made by Congress and the executive branch, in theory, shouldn't be able to stop it for long.

What will be more interesting(albeit also scary and dangerous) is what happens if the executive branch starts to ignore judicial rulings that they don't like.

If Congress sits around and concedes authority to the executive branch and the judicial branch turns out to be toothless, that kind of defeats the whole checks and balances concept that we've leaned on for so long. From there the executive can do whatever, no?

So, it looks like this isn't a particularly strong ruling against Trump, despite the headline, given that it basically shifts responsibility back down to the lower court.

At least that's something, I guess?

In any case, we'll see if Trump decides to Jackson this.
Whenever I hear even moderately good news from SCOTUS, I immediately fear that it's a bone being thrown to the Left right before an awful ruling for Trump.

posts.title: FIRE files federal lawsuit against top Texas A&M administrators
top_comments:
“The Foundation for Individual Rights and Expression, or FIRE, has filed a federal lawsuit against the nine members of the Board of Regents, Chancellor John Sharp and Texas A&M President Mark A. Welsh III on behalf of the Queer Empowerment Council, the student organization that hosts and organizes Draggieland.”

Keep the lawsuits coming. Freedom of speech, freedom from persecution and discrimination are the building blocks of our democracy.

What ever happened to just not attending if you're not interested? I mean, it's not the sort of thing I'd go out of my way to see, but I can always just... you know... not attend. When I was in college there would occasionally be some wandering preacher guy who'd show up on campus for a couple days. I wasn't really interested in his message, so I just kept walking. A very simple and elegant solution that didn't involve me trying to impose my personal beliefs on anyone else. I just would have appreciated someone from the campus security doing a bit of crowd control since people listening would often block the entire sidewalk which was a major thoroughfare.

And honestly, nothing beats the name of a SF group: The Sisters of Perpetual Indulgence

posts.title: Supreme Court rejects Trump’s request to keep billions in foreign aid frozen
top_comments:
Alito’s dissent is some choice bullshit. “How dare a lower court override the president!”

The lower court found that congress had specified money to be spent, and the executive branch can’t just say “Nah.” They can slow walk it, they can do some other shady shit - but in the end they gotta pay out that money. 

Alito’s so concerned about someone overturning the president he’s saying the statutes congress passed don’t matter.

It’s kind of mind boggling that 4 Supreme Court Justices support the idea that the Executive branch can just deicide not to pay their bills when the Legislative branch has allocated the funding and the recipients have already done what they were to be paid to do.
OK, so now let’s see if trump complies and if he doesn’t, then what?
Damn Justice Amy Coney Barrett doing justice.

That there are only five SCOTUS votes for paying congressionally mandated invoices for work *already* done!? This should be as basic a test of Article I as you can get. And that does not bode well for decisions to come

“Four of the court’s conservatives — Justices Clarence Thomas, Samuel Alito, Neil Gorsuch and Brett Kavanaugh — dissented.”

These are the men who will dismantle our democracy. 

So shocked by Coney Barrett. I guess he does understand the Constitution and the benefit of rule of law. 

BTW- this ruling merely states that the USG must pay for work already done by implementers. This is money owed to them.
Hallelujah. I haven’t been keeping up too much with which justices vote for what so maybe this is normal, but I was surprised to see Amy Coney Barrett voted with the liberal justices.

Interesting that 2 conservatives, including 1 Trump appointee in Barrett ruled against Trump. Though maybe not so much considering how relatively extreme this case is. The decision to spend this money is made by Congress and the executive branch, in theory, shouldn't be able to stop it for long.

What will be more interesting(albeit also scary and dangerous) is what happens if the executive branch starts to ignore judicial rulings that they don't like.

If Congress sits around and concedes authority to the executive branch and the judicial branch turns out to be toothless, that kind of defeats the whole checks and balances concept that we've leaned on for so long. From there the executive can do whatever, no?

So, it looks like this isn't a particularly strong ruling against Trump, despite the headline, given that it basically shifts responsibility back down to the lower court.

At least that's something, I guess?

In any case, we'll see if Trump decides to Jackson this.

posts.title: Piglets left to starve as part of a controversial art exhibition in Denmark have been stolen
top_comments:
Good on the activists who stole them and the guy who helped. This artist is nuts. What an awful person.

 This just seems extra cruel for no real end game, like its not going to stop anyone from anything, it was suffering for the sake of "art".
This the same artist that did the goldfish in blenders?
This is not art it’s animal cruelty

> Chilean-born Marco Evaristti said he had been aiming to raise awareness of the suffering caused by mass meat production with his art installation that opened last week in Copenhagen. The piglets were being denied food and water and would have been allowed to starve to death.

I don't think the way to advocate against animal cruelty, is to cause more animal cruelty. Especially when you're subjecting a creature to a slow death that is initially pretty agonizing.
Suffering for his art is probably a good thing. Replace the missing pigs in the cage with the artist - maybe it will make the same point.

It is kind of interesting that everyone is very upset by this but not upset when it is done in factory farms. I think that is the point of this. Not defending it but I wish some of you would reflect on how this mirrors industrial farming techniques.
I’m inclined to think this artist is actually a psychopath.  Performing animal cruelty to point out other people’s cruelty is certainly a choice.

There was an artist a while back who did something like this with a dog. Guillermo Vargas brought in a starving street dog from outside and had it in the art gallery for 3 hours - the gallery reported that he did feed it food and water while it was there, before it "escaped." Guests were shocked and complained about it, and the artist's point was basically, it's the same dog you walked past outside but didn't give a shit about.

I'm going out on a limb here and braving the wall of downvotes.


The provocation artist achived what he wanted without harming the piglets. They were never starved, they were not even showcased.


Yet he managed to upset so many people, that it sparked an outrage highlighting the fact most people don't give two shits about animals dying, as long as they are out of sight. What can be more artful than getting people to reflect on issues they normally wouldn't?


The comments in this post are beyond disappointing and shows they have no grasp on art at all.

Maybe, just maybe, the theft of the piglets is all part of the art exhibition. I’m not sure this is the case given that the exhibition opened last week. 

If the intention was to allow three piglets to die from thirst there is a special place in hell for the artist. 

“Chilean-born Marco Evaristti said he had been aiming to raise awareness of the suffering caused by mass meat production with his art installation that opened last week in Copenhagen. The piglets were being denied food and water and would have been allowed to starve to death.”

They wouldn’t have starved to death, they would have died of thirst.
